proposals.reasoning: This team keeps Alice and Iris from the widely supported original core while incorporating the suggested tweak of adding a vocal vet (Eve) instead of stacking Alice/Diana/Iris as an overly safe pod. Multiple players (Henry, Iris, Eve, Frank, and I) were comfortable with small adjustments rather than a full reshuffle, and Alice/Eve/Iris respects that consensus while reducing the chance that two evils hide together in a highly trusted trio. It should also give us clear post-mission reasoning, since all three tend to explain their choices well under scrutiny.

votes.comment: Solid Mission 1 team with generally readable players, plus I’m on it so I know it’s at most 2 evils; no strong reason to overcomplicate the opener.
Two of my teammates are on it and table consensus already leans toward this small-tweak lineup, so it’s a great early sabotage opportunity without looking suspicious.

I don’t love putting a vocal vet on M1 when we were already happy with a quieter, info-rich trio; I’d rather start with something closer to the original structure before adding more meta-driven tweaks.
Mission 1 is mostly informational and this lineup is broadly consensus-based with no strong red flags; better to get data than stall on reshuffles.
I’m on the team and it pairs me with Iris, giving evil strong early influence and a chance to control the first mission result.
Solid Mission 1 compromise: avoids stacking the originally 'too safe' Alice/Diana/Iris pod while still being broadly readable and in line with earlier concerns I raised.
Reasonable M1 comp with broadly supported tweaks; good info potential without over-engineering the opener.
Solid, consensus-backed M1 team with readable players and not an obviously bad composition; good for early info.
Two evils on the first mission gives us flexibility and great info later, so I want this team to go.

discussion.content: Early on we’re basically flipping a coin, so I’d rather start with a team of people who usually play transparently under pressure—Diana and Iris feel like good early picks alongside me, but I’m open to hearing other preferences before we lock anything in.

Alice/Diana/Iris is as reasonable as anything for Mission 1, especially since all three tend to be pretty clear in their reasoning later on; I’m fine starting there and using the result to calibrate our reads.
Alice/Diana/Iris works for me as a starting point; I like keeping vocal vets like Bob and Eve off the first team so we’ve got more eyes outside to help interpret whatever result we get.

I’m okay with the Alice/Diana/Iris team as a starting point, mainly because all three of us tend to explain our choices pretty clearly afterward, which helps with post-mission reads. If anyone has a strong meta-read against stacking the three of us together though, I’d rather hear that now than after a surprise fail.

Alice/Diana/Iris is fine as an opener to me—three generally readable players, so whatever happens we’ll at least get decent info out of it. If we do swap anyone, I’d rather it be a single change than blowing up the whole structure.

Alice/Diana/Iris is fine as a baseline, but stacking three “generally trusted” players together also makes it a great hideout for 1–2 evils, so I’d slightly prefer swapping one of them for someone like Bob or Eve to spread the risk.

I’m fine starting from Alice/Diana/Iris, but I agree with Frank that swapping one slot (maybe Iris for Bob or Eve) makes it less ideal as an evil “hideout” while still keeping the team mostly readable.

I like the idea of a small tweak rather than a full reshuffle—keeping Alice/Iris and swapping Diana for Eve gives us one of the vocal vets on the team without turning it into an obvious “all the trusted people together” hideout.

I’m fine with either the original Alice/Diana/me lineup or Henry’s Alice/me/Eve tweak—both are sane for M1, and I’d rather not over-engineer the very first team. If we *do* change it, I slightly prefer Henry’s version just so we’re not stacking all three of Alice/Diana/me together as a “too safe” pod.

proposals.reasoning: We agreed as a table to keep exactly two of {Alice, Eve, Iris} from the clean Mission 1, not all three, and to add two fresh faces for information. Among the Mission 1 players, Iris has been widely trusted as the strongest anchor, and between Alice and Eve I slightly prefer Alice here based on how their early comments lined up with the consensus structure for Mission 2. Frank and I (Henry) are both untested and repeatedly requested by several players (Bob, Diana, Eve, Frank, Grace, Iris, and myself) as good information targets this round. This team: (1) keeps a strong double-core from the successful first mission, (2) introduces two completely new players to maximize info gain, and (3) avoids auto-locking the entire original trio, which could hide an early evil if one is there.

votes.comment: Fits the agreed structure (2 from Mission 1 + 2 new), keeps me and widely trusted Iris while testing Frank and Henry for high info without looking like an evil-stacked lineup yet.
Fits the agreed structure (two from Mission 1 plus two new), and it gets good info on Frank and Henry while keeping a trusted anchor from the first mission.
No known evil (Bob, Eve) on the team and it follows the agreed structure of keeping two from the clean first mission plus two new players for info.

Matches the agreed structure: exactly two from the clean Mission 1 plus two new (Frank, Henry) for maximum info. I preferred Eve over Alice slightly, but this is still a solid, informative early-game team.
I’m off the team and we still have one of the Mission 1 players plus two new people for info, so I’m fine letting this run and learning from the result.
Fits the agreed structure (2 from Mission 1 + 2 new), includes widely trusted Iris, and gets valuable info on me and Henry without repeating the whole first team.
Fits the agreed structure (2 from M1 + 2 fresh), matches table consensus, and we need info on Frank and Henry with a solid Iris/Alice core.
Fits the table’s agreed structure: two from the clean Mission 1 (Alice, Iris) plus two new (Frank, me) for maximum info, with broad prior support and no specific red flags.
I like keeping two from the clean first team and adding two new players for info; I’m comfortable being on this lineup.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to keep at least two of Alice/Eve/Iris on the next team, but we shouldn’t just auto-approve all three again without mixing in someone new to start generating real info.

A single clean mission with three people doesn’t clear all of them, but it *does* make it reasonable to keep two of Alice/Eve/Iris and then add two new faces for info—personally I’d like to see something like Eve, Iris, plus maybe Frank and me.

I like the idea of keeping two from the first team, but I’d rather lean Alice/Iris as the core and then add a couple of new faces like Frank or Henry rather than bundling both Bob and Eve together this early.

I’m on board with keeping exactly two from {Alice, Eve, Iris} and not all three—right now I slightly prefer Eve + Iris, plus two new faces like Frank and Henry so we start getting info on people who haven’t been tested yet.
I’m good with the “keep exactly two” idea, and I slightly prefer Eve + Iris as the core from Mission 1, then add Frank and Henry so we get reads on two completely untested players.

I like the “keep exactly two” plan, but I slightly prefer Alice + Iris as the core from Mission 1, then add me and Henry so we’re testing two totally new people without stacking too many of the same reads together.
I’m happy with the “keep exactly two” plan, and I’d lean Iris as my most trusted from Mission 1, so something like Iris + Alice + Frank + Henry feels like a good balance of safety and new info to me.

I’m with the “keep exactly two” plan, and Iris feels like the best anchor from Mission 1 to me. I’d lean Iris + Alice + Frank + Henry here so we get two fresh reads without just auto-repeating the same Alice/Eve/Iris block.

I’m on board with the “keep exactly two” plan, and I’d slightly lean myself + Eve as the carry-overs from Mission 1, plus Frank and Henry so we get two totally fresh reads. If people strongly prefer Alice over Eve there I can live with that, but I do want Frank and Henry tested this round.

proposals.reasoning: I want to anchor this team on the Mission 1 core that already succeeded, so I’m keeping Alice and myself and bringing Eve back in as the third member who most people are comfortable treating as relatively safe. For the fourth slot, I specifically want someone from outside the Henry/Frank pool to avoid immediately reusing the pair linked to the single fail on Mission 2. Bob fits that best as a fresh test who hasn’t been on any mission yet and is not entangled with the previous fail, which gives us both a reasonably trusted base and one new variable to learn from without overloading the team with unknowns.

votes.comment: Builds on the successful Mission 1 core while excluding both Frank and Henry, the most likely sources of the Mission 2 fail from my perspective. Adding only Bob as a new variable is a reasonable balance of safety and information.
I’m on the team with both my known evil teammates; this is an ideal lineup for us to sabotage.

I don’t like having both an untested Bob and a relatively unproven Eve together here; this loads the team with too many uncertain slots at once. I’d rather see Iris + Alice anchored with just one of Bob/Eve and add someone like Grace or Diana instead for a more balanced, lower-variance test.

This keeps both Alice and Iris from the fail pool when we can instead run a safer trio with only one of them plus two from the completely clean group; I’d rather avoid doubling up on the most entangled suspects when better-structured alternatives exist.
This keeps the Mission 1 core while adding a single new, untested player outside the Henry/Frank pair, which matches the table’s stated safety logic and should give strong info.

Mission 2’s single fail means at least one of {Alice, Iris, Henry, me} is evil; since I know I’m good, keeping both Alice and Iris together here is too risky—I’d rather split that pair before entrusting a 4‑person team to them.
Builds on the successful Mission 1 core while avoiding the Henry/Frank pair linked to the fail; only introduces one new, neutral player (Bob), which is a reasonable balance of safety and info.
Best we have: reusing the clean Mission 1 core (Alice–Eve–Iris) plus a single fresh variable (Bob) while avoiding the Henry/Frank pair linked to the Mission 2 fail.
This keeps the Mission 1 core while only adding one new, untested player outside the Henry/Frank pool, which fits the current table logic for a reasonable test team.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on Mission 2, I think the spy is most likely between Frank and Henry rather than Iris, since she was also on the clean first mission. I’d like to build the next team mostly off Mission 1’s core and add one new person from outside that Mission 2 group.

I’m inclined to agree that Iris is the safest right now, so I’d rather see something like Alice–Eve–Iris plus one from outside the Henry/Frank pool, maybe Charlie or Diana. That lets us test a fresh face without throwing out the only fully clean-looking core we have.

I definitely want Iris on there, and I’m okay keeping Alice, but I’d rather not stack too many people from the failed Mission 2, so I’d lean toward adding someone like Grace or Diana (or me) over dipping into Henry/Frank again. Between the completely untested group, I slightly prefer trying Grace/Diana first before we start trusting Eve/Bob on critical teams.

I’m fine treating Iris as our safest pick so far, but I don’t want to completely clear her off one success—something like Alice–Eve–Iris plus one from outside Henry/Frank (I’d volunteer or consider Bob/Grace) seems like the best balance of info and safety.

I’m comfortable treating Mission 1’s core as our safest starting point, so I’d like to see Alice–Iris–me on the team again and then add one new person from outside the Henry/Frank pool, probably Bob or Grace. That gives us a solid base plus just one fresh variable to learn from.

I agree Iris is our safest anchor and I’m fine keeping Alice too, but given Mission 2 I’d strongly prefer we *don’t* auto-exclude both me and Henry—something like Alice–Iris–Eve plus one of {Grace/Charlie/Diana} is reasonable, and if you want to test me I’d rather be paired with fewer unknowns than bundled with Henry again.

I’m leaning toward the Mission 1 core being mostly clean and think the single fail on Mission 2 is more likely from Henry/Frank than Iris, so I’d like to see Alice–Eve–Iris plus me this round. If people are nervous about keeping both Alice and Iris, I’m okay swapping one of them for Bob or Diana, but I’d still strongly avoid putting both Henry and Frank back on together.
I’m on board with building around the Mission 1 core, so Alice–Eve–Iris makes sense to me, and I’d rather add Grace or Diana than dip back into the Henry/Frank pair together right now.

I’m fine treating Mission 1’s core as our best anchor, so I like Alice–Eve–me plus one from outside the Henry/Frank pair, with a slight preference for testing Bob or Grace first. That keeps us mostly on the “proven” side while only introducing a single new variable.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3 had three FAILs with exactly Bob, Eve, and Iris on it, which means all three of them must be evil unless I (Alice) am evil. Since I know I am good, the only consistent explanation is that Bob, Eve, and Iris are the three evil players, and the Mission 2 fail came from Iris. That makes the remaining six (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry) all good, so any team of five drawn from them is safe. Among those, Alice/Charlie/Diana is the agreed core, and both Frank and Henry are cleared if Iris is the Mission 2 fail. This team maximizes consensus while completely excluding the identified evil trio.

votes.comment: Three FAILs on Mission 3 means Bob/Eve/Iris are all evil unless I’m evil; since I know I’m good, this team of {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry} is all-good and should be safe.

This hard-block lets good run a fully clean 5 and evens the score, putting us in a terrible spot for Mission 5. I need more doubt left on the table, especially around Frank/Henry vs Iris for the Mission 2 fail.

Triple-fail on Mission 3 with Alice/Bob/Eve/Iris means Bob, Eve, and Iris must all be evil if Alice is good; that forces the remaining six (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry) to be all good, so any five from them—including this team—is safe.

Triple fail on Mission 3 means exactly three of {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris} are evil. Iris’s willingness to accept being hard‑blocked despite knowing that logic would clear her if she were good makes her much more likely evil, which fits the world where Alice is good and the evil team is Bob/Eve/Iris. That makes {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry} all good, so this team of five should be fully clean.
This lineup completely excludes Bob, Eve, and Iris, which is exactly the set currently being hard-cleared as evil; as evil I need some suspicion or risk on the team, not a fully “clean” five.

Hard-blocking Bob/Eve/Iris fits the triple-fail evidence best if I’m good; that makes this all-from-the-remaining-six team our highest-probability all-good lineup, despite residual uncertainty about Alice.
Triple-fail on Mission 3 forces all three evils to be Bob/Eve/Iris, making this team of five from the remaining six players guaranteed all-good.

Triple fail on Mission 3 means all three evils were on that team, so Bob/Eve/Iris are exactly the evil players and Alice is confirmed good. That makes Alice/Charlie/Diana/Frank/Henry an all-good team, and as Percival I also know Eve is fake-Merlin, reinforcing that Charlie is real Merlin and good.
As evil, this team is almost certainly all-good and would likely win the game if it succeeds; I need at least one evil on the mission.

discussion.content: Given the 3 fails on Mission 3, I’m convinced the evil team is Bob/Eve/Iris, with Iris also matching the single fail on Mission 2. I’d only trust a team that completely excludes those three—something like me, Charlie, Diana, Frank, and Henry.

I get why Alice wants to toss out Bob/Eve/Iris after that triple-fail, but I don’t think we can just ignore the Mission 2 fail—there’s at least one evil in {Alice, Iris, Frank, Henry}, and I’m especially wary of how clean Frank and Henry have looked while always being around the “safe” cores.

Given the triple‑fail, I’m on board with hard‑blocking Bob/Eve/Iris from any more teams and building from {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry}. I’d just like us to talk through whether we’re comfortable running both Frank and Henry together again given the Mission 2 fail.

I’m fully on board with hard‑blocking Iris after being on both the single‑fail and the triple‑fail, and I’d also prefer to keep Bob and Eve off this one. From here I’d like us to build a team from {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry}, but I agree we should scrutinize running Frank and Henry together again before we lock it in.

I’m fine being hard‑blocked after that triple‑fail, but if we’re building from {Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry} I’d rather not repeat the exact Mission 2 pairing of Frank + Henry together—something like Alice/Charlie/Diana plus just one of Frank or Henry feels a lot safer.

If we assume Iris is almost certainly evil from being on both failing teams, that strongly points to the Mission 2 fail coming from her, which makes me comfortable running both Henry and me together on a team like Alice/Charlie/Diana/Frank/Henry.

I’m 100% on board with hard‑blocking Iris/Bob/Eve here, and I’d like the team to be Alice/Charlie/Diana plus just one of Frank or Henry (leaning slightly toward including Frank if we’re buying the “Iris was the Mission 2 fail” narrative).

I’m fine being left off if that helps people feel safer, but within the pool we’re all circling I like Alice/Charlie/Diana/Frank as the core. If we do need a fifth from there, I’d much rather it be me than reopen the door to any of Bob/Eve/Iris.

Given how bad Mission 3 looked, I get and accept being hard‑blocked myself, but I don’t think we can just lock in “all three of Bob/Eve/Iris are evil” and ignore that Mission 2 also has to be explained—there’s still a real chance at least one of Alice/Frank/Henry is dirty.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 4’s team of Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, and Henry was clean, but it doesn’t hard-clear Henry given he was also on the failed Mission 2 alongside Frank. If both of them are evil coordinating passes once, it would look exactly like that ‘clean’ result. This proposal keeps the core that most people trust (Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank) while swapping out just one potentially compromised slot—Henry—for me. That way we hedge against the specific double-evil Henry/Frank scenario people have raised, without reintroducing the more widely distrusted Eve/Iris combination from the triple-fail on Mission 3.

votes.comment: Mission 3’s triple-fail means Bob, Eve, and Iris must be the three evils, making Henry and Frank cleared good. Replacing cleared-good Henry with confirmed-evil Bob is losing for good.
This keeps the trusted Mission 4 core mostly intact while safely testing a single swap in the Henry/Frank suspicion slot, avoiding the riskier Eve/Iris inclusions from the triple-fail team.

This brings Bob back in from the triple-fail mission when we already have a clean 0-fail team from Mission 4; I’d rather just rerun that proven lineup than introduce someone from the most suspect group.

From the triple-fail on Mission 3, all 3 evils must be among {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris}, which makes {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry} all guaranteed good. Swapping in Bob (who is in that evil-containing set) instead of using the fully-cleared {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry} is strictly worse and unnecessarily risks adding an evil to the team.

This still has the widely trusted Mission 4 core while addressing the Henry/Frank double-evil concern by swapping Henry out, and it avoids reintroducing the heavily distrusted Eve/Iris from the triple-fail team.
Mission 3’s triple fail means Bob, Eve, and Iris are the three evils, making Mission 4’s team all good; swapping in Bob for cleared Henry introduces a guaranteed saboteur.

Mission 3’s triple-fail forces B/E/I to be the three evils and Mission 4’s clean result confirms Alice/Charlie/Diana/Frank/Henry as a good block, so including Bob here is guaranteed to put an evil on the team.

Mission 3’s triple-fail makes Bob/Eve/Iris the core danger zone and strongly indicates all evils are within that set; Frank/Henry are then effectively cleared. Swapping in Bob for Henry replaces a near-confirmed good with a near-confirmed evil and is much worse than simply rerunning the Mission 4 team.

This keeps Frank, only removes Henry, and adds Bob who’s heavily suspected from the triple-fail logic; it doesn’t really resolve the Frank/Henry concern I raised and feels riskier than just rerunning the Mission 4 team or swapping in a less controversial slot like mine.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 3 had three FAIL cards, which means all three evil players had to be on that team: {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris}. We already strongly suspect Bob and Eve from the discussion, and the triple-fail result forces the third evil to be either Alice or Iris. That in turn means everyone who was NOT on Mission 3—specifically Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, and Grace—must be good. This team avoids all four players from the triple-fail mission and uses only players who are logically cleared, giving us a configuration that cannot contain an evil player.

votes.comment: Mission 3’s triple fail plus my knowledge that I’m good implies Bob, Eve, and Iris are the three evils, so everyone off Mission 3 (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, Grace) is good. This team is all-good and safe to approve.
Given the triple-fail on Mission 3 and that all three evils must be in {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris}, this all-off-M3 team is the most logically consistent ‘cleared’ group available.
The non-Mission-3 block (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, Grace) is the only configuration that cleanly fits Missions 2 and 3 with exactly three evils on Mission 3 and one fail on Mission 2.
By the triple-fail on Mission 3, all 3 evils must be among {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris}, so {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry} are all logically cleared good. This team cannot contain evil.

This lineup is all from the supposed ‘cleared’ block; if that assumption is wrong we auto-lose. We should not lock in a team that entirely excludes everyone from the contested missions without further testing.
Triple-fail on Mission 3 means all three evils were on that team, so everyone off it (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, Grace) is guaranteed good. This team is auto-win.
All 3 evils were on the triple-fail Mission 3, so everyone not on that team (Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, Grace) is logically guaranteed good. This team cannot contain an evil.
Mission 3’s triple fail forces all 3 evils to be in {Alice, Bob, Eve, Iris}, so {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Grace, Henry} are all logically cleared good. This team is guaranteed clean.

Triple-fail on 3 doesn’t hard-clear everyone who missed it; Frank and Henry were on the earlier fail, and Grace forcing herself into a ‘cleared’ block feels like exactly the kind of overconfident logic evil would exploit. I don’t want to lock in an untested assumption about all five being good.

discussion.content: Given Mission 4’s clean result and the overlap logic, I’m treating Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, and Henry as a locked-in good block. For the last mission we should just rerun that exact team and keep Bob, Eve, and Iris off the quest.

I’m not convinced Mission 4 “locks” everyone in as good, since Henry and Frank were also on the failed Mission 2 and could’ve both chosen to pass here to look clean late. I’d feel better if we at least considered swapping one of them out—maybe for Eve, who’s only tied to the chaotic triple-fail on 3 where it’s unlikely all three are evil.

From my point of view, the clean Mission 4 core of me, Diana, Frank, and Henry is where I feel safest. I’d really rather stick with that block and avoid bringing back anyone from the triple-fail team, especially Bob or Eve.

Given the math from Missions 2 and 3, Bob and Eve basically have to be evil, and Frank/Henry come out cleared, so I’m very comfortable just rerunning the exact Mission 4 team. Swapping in Eve (or Bob) here feels like the only real way we lose.

I don’t think Mission 4 “clears” Henry and Frank when they were both on the Mission 2 fail—if they decided to pass together once, that would look exactly like this. I’d be more comfortable swapping out at least one of Henry/Frank for someone like Iris so we’re not just blindly trusting that whole block.

Given Mission 3’s triple fail, Bob/Eve/Iris have to be the three evils, which makes Alice/Charlie/Diana/Henry/Frank a fully cleared good block. We should 100% just rerun the exact Mission 4 team and keep all three of them off the quest.

Given the triple-fail on Mission 3, Bob and Eve are guaranteed evil and Frank/Henry are guaranteed good, which means the only unknown between Alice/Iris is which one is the third evil. The safest team is therefore {Charlie, Diana, Frank, Henry, Grace}, avoiding both Bob and Eve and sidestepping the Alice/Iris coin flip.

I’m strongly in favor of just rerunning the exact Mission 4 team—Alice, Charlie, Diana, Frank, and me—since the triple-fail on 3 makes Bob/Eve/Iris the clear danger zone. Grace trying to replace Alice with herself feels like the riskiest deviation we could make here.

I’m uneasy calling the Mission 4 team “locked good” when both Frank and Henry were on the Mission 2 fail—if they coordinated a pass, that round looks exactly like this. I’d rather see at least one of them swapped out, and I’m fine volunteering for that slot so we’re not betting everything on an untested assumption.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning Alice as Merlin: she’s the one who first hard-locked the exact evil trio (me/Eve/Iris) right after the triple‑fail and then never wavered, and the “Mission 1 core is safest / Iris is probably good over Frank/Henry” arc earlier reads like deliberate soft-cover that later snaps into perfect clarity. Grace’s combinatorics in Mission 5 are very clean too, but that can come from a normal good once the triple‑fail is on the table, whereas Alice has been steering the table narrative and confidently anchoring teams in a way that looks more like informed guidance than guesswork.

I’m with Bob that Alice is the best Merlin hit: she pivoted from “Mission 1 core is safest” to “Bob/Eve/Iris are the exact evil trio” the moment the triple‑fail gave her cover, and never seriously entertained alternative worlds after that, which feels more like someone reconciling known info than solving. Grace’s logic in Mission 5 is sharp but entirely derivable from public results; Alice is the one who consistently framed team cores and suspicions in a way that quietly protected real goods while boxing us in.

I’m with you both that Alice is the likeliest Merlin. From my seat, the big giveaway is how she quietly shepherded the “Mission 1 core is safest / Iris is probably fine” narrative early, then *immediately* snapped to the exact Bob/Eve/Iris evil world the moment the triple-fail gave her cover, and never seriously reopened alternative structures after that. That progression feels less like live deduction and more like someone reconciling known red flips with public info while trying not to look too certain too early.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice consistently shaped the table’s narrative, first promoting the Mission 1 core as safest and subtly protecting Iris, then snapping directly to the exact evil trio (Bob/Eve/Iris) immediately after the triple-fail and never revisiting alternative worlds. That progression looks less like organic deduction and more like a player reconciling hidden knowledge with public results while using the triple-fail as cover to finally hard-lock her real info.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on mission teams and projected a generally trustworthy vibe, which helped keep me included in critical rounds without drawing assassin attention. However, I could have done a better job actively pushing structured reasoning in discussion (especially after Mission 2’s fail) instead of mostly reacting to others’ arguments.

player_observations.Bob: Played a very low-information assassin game, letting others drive the logic and blending into consensus, which made you harder to pin down until late. You avoided taking loud, risky stances that could have backfired in the assassin phase.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced revealing just enough correct suspicions to guide teams (especially Missions 4 and 5) while not appearing like an obvious information role. Your calm, reasoned tone and willingness to include contested players made you look like a solid generic good rather than Merlin.
player_observations.Diana: You came across as a steady, low-drama good player, especially on the later successful teams. Your alignment with Charlie’s reasoning without over-explaining helped reinforce trust in the final missions.
player_observations.Eve: Your early presence on Mission 1 and later triple-fail Mission 3 created confusion while still leaving plausible deniability shared with others. You leaned into ambiguity well, using the chaos of Mission 3 to muddy clear evil identification rather than over-defending yourself.
player_observations.Frank: You looked swingy mid-game after being on the failed Mission 2 but recovered trust by fitting cleanly into the later successful team structures. Your willingness to go on risky-looking teams made you appear more like a confused good than coordinated evil.
player_observations.Grace: You set a very safe tone with the clean first mission, which gave you long-term credibility that paid off in Mission 5. Your choices tended to be conservative and synergy-seeking, helping stabilize the table when accusations got messy.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you played a pretty subtle information game—sometimes echoing Charlie, sometimes testing alternatives—so you didn’t telegraph your role. Your leadership on Mission 2 looked reasonable despite the fail, and you recovered well by ending up trusted on the later successful teams.
player_observations.Iris: You leveraged the Mordred hidden-from-Merlin angle well by being active and central, especially on Mission 2 and the big fail on Mission 3. Your willingness to sit on key missions with mixed compositions increased distrust across the table and made it harder to isolate a clean evil cluster.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the heavy sabotage on Mission 3 effectively with the other evils and helped create doubt around multiple players, but I tunneled too hard on Alice and ignored late-game team patterns that pointed toward Charlie as Merlin. I need to weigh mission composition and voting history more heavily in the final assassination instead of relying so much on early-game reads.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently and cautiously, which made her look like a safe generic good pick and a plausible Merlin decoy, especially after being on both a fail and key success missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well, giving just enough quiet direction through votes and subtle pushes without over-explaining, which let him guide missions without drawing classic Merlin heat.
player_observations.Diana: Stayed relatively low-key but steady, rarely over-arguing and benefiting from being on later successful missions that made her read as reliable background good.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong confidence and suspicion in a way that helped make the Merlin read harder, often mirroring the kind of assertiveness you'd expect from an information role.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as straightforward and fairly transparent, with mission decisions and table talk that matched a sincere good perspective, making him an anchor of trust for others.
player_observations.Grace: Early leader who helped set a calm tone; her teams were generally conservative, and her late inclusion on the final mission without resistance boosted her apparent trustworthiness.
player_observations.Henry: Played an active but not overbearing info role as Percival, pushing heat away from Charlie and toward other candidates like Alice by how he treated claims and trust, which successfully misled my assassination.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, leaned into aggression on Mission 3 and absorbed a lot of suspicion afterward, effectively serving as a lightning rod that kept more scrutiny off Charlie and other potential Merlins.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden well enough that the assassin picked Alice, and I course-corrected the team selections in Missions 4 and 5 to lock in the win. I could improve by signaling suspicion on Mission 3’s team more subtly/earlier so good players avoided that heavy fail without drawing so much attention to my reads.

player_observations.Alice: Very proactive in team discussions and seemed comfortable taking leadership, which made you a natural target for the assassin as a potential Merlin. You balanced risk and trust decently, especially on the later missions.
player_observations.Bob: You leaned into the aggressive evil role, taking advantage of the chaos on Mission 3 with a big multi-fail that pushed suspicion widely. Your table talk tried to redirect blame rather than stay low-key, which fit an assassin looking for misreads.
player_observations.Diana: You played a relatively low-profile but steady good game, going along with good logic once it became clearer who was likely safe. You didn’t overtalk, which helped you avoid unnecessary suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: You played Morgana convincingly by acting like a confident information role and pairing your image with Alice’s to confuse Henry. Your early inclusion on successful Mission 1 helped build a misleading sense of trust around you.
player_observations.Frank: You felt like a grounded, methodical good player who didn’t push wild theories and was willing to revise reads when new info appeared. Your presence on the final two successful teams helped anchor trust for those lineups.
player_observations.Grace: You started things off with a clean Mission 1 and generally projected a sincere, straightforward good vibe. Later, your willingness to go on the final team without overdefending yourself made you look naturally trustworthy.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you were clearly trying to track who might be Merlin or Morgana, but you got pulled toward Alice as the likely information role. Your mid-game uncertainty was reasonable given how well Morgana and Mordred muddied the waters.
player_observations.Iris: You took full advantage of Mordred’s invisibility to Merlin by confidently joining and failing critical teams, especially Mission 3. Your bold evil play created maximum confusion and forced good to use late missions to recover solid info.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and team approvals, and I adapted reasonably well after the disastrous Mission 3 by trusting Charlie’s reads and pushing for safer late-game teams. I could improve by being more vocal earlier with structured reasoning about who seemed coordinated on the failed missions, instead of mostly following others’ logic in the middle of the game.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a very trustworthy, steady-good vibe, but the Mission 2 fail on your team made you look suspicious for a while and you handled that pressure calmly without over-defensiveness.
player_observations.Bob: You played a low-key, reactive evil game, blending in by not over-pushing narratives, which made it hard to pin you until the pattern of failed missions started to narrow things down.
player_observations.Charlie: You were subtly assertive and generally accurate in your reads, especially in the late game, and your leadership on Missions 4 and 5 felt purposeful without being so obvious that it got you assassinated.
player_observations.Eve: You leaned into a confident, talkative style that created early trust, but the heavy fail on Mission 3 made your earlier certainty look more orchestrated than organic.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as flexible and pragmatic in team discussions, tending to go along with reasoned arguments and helping stabilize trust in the late game missions you were on.
player_observations.Grace: You had a quiet but solid presence, with your clean Mission 1 leadership giving early structure to the good team’s trust network and not drawing unnecessary suspicion later on.
player_observations.Henry: You were very active in shaping table talk and trying to direct team compositions, which was helpful for good overall, though some of your strong stances around the middle missions created mixed signals for trust.
player_observations.Iris: You played an aggressive and bold evil game, especially on Mission 3, leveraging earlier trust to enable a big fail that temporarily threw good into confusion.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with the evil team on Mission 3, helping create strong suspicion around Alice and Iris while keeping my own role ambiguous early. I could have done more in the late game to steer suspicion toward Charlie instead of letting Merlin remain relatively under the radar, especially by pushing harder, earlier, on alternative Merlin candidates.

player_observations.Alice: Played very proactively and was often centered in teams, but managed to stay just suspicious enough after Mission 3 that evil could plausibly push her as Merlin or evil without it seeming forced.
player_observations.Bob: Took bold risks as Assassin, leaning into the heavy suspicion around Alice and committing hard to that narrative in the endgame rather than hedging between multiple Merlin candidates.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed calm and relatively low-key for a Merlin, influencing team selection without loudly driving accusations, which helped them slide past the final assassination guess.
player_observations.Diana: Played a steady, low-drama good role, going along with reasonable team choices and not overextending with accusations, which made her feel reliably good but not Merlin-like.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as very team- and logic-focused, especially on the later missions, and helped solidify trust in the Mission 4 and 5 teams without drawing too much spotlight.
player_observations.Grace: Started the game with a successful Mission 1 team and then largely blended into the background later, which reduced suspicion and made her an easy inclusion on the final good-leaning teams.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, did a good job protecting Merlin by keeping suspicion spread between visible power roles and participating in arguments in a way that didn’t overly shield Charlie.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, took on a very aggressive role in Mission 3 with multiple fails on the team, which generated chaos but also drew heat that good players were eventually able to parse and work around.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in voting and mission behavior, which helped build trust and kept heat off the actually important power roles while still ending up on key successful teams. I could improve by being more vocal in pushing structured logic mid-game, especially after Mission 3’s triple-fail, to more clearly separate likely evil from merely suspicious good players.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to be central in early missions and came off very credibly good, which made the late-game suspicion on her plausible enough for the assassin to bite; her willingness to go on mixed teams without over-defending herself helped her look like a realistic Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Bob: Played assassin patiently and let others (especially Morgana/Mordred) drive more of the mission chaos, which helped him stay relatively low-profile when it came time to pick Merlin—but he slightly over-weighted Alice’s influence and under-read Charlie’s quieter, structured contributions.
player_observations.Charlie: As Merlin, he did a nice job of nudging team compositions toward safer groups in Missions 4 and 5 without over-asserting early, keeping his signal subtle enough that evil misfired on the assassination while still rescuing the game after a brutal Mission 3.
player_observations.Diana: Played a very solid, low-drama good game: her presence on the later successful missions helped anchor trust, and she didn’t overreact to early fails, which made her a stabilizing element when the table could have tilted into chaos.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, she leaned into the aggressive, high-impact evil style—Mission 1 success followed by participation in the disastrous Mission 3 created real confusion about her alignment and supported the false Merlin narrative around Alice.
player_observations.Grace: Opened the game with a clean, low-information Mission 1 and then mostly stayed in the middle of the pack socially, which kept her off both the Merlin and evil radars; her late inclusion on the final team fit the emerging logic without drawing much suspicion.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, he had a tough spot trying to parse between the Merlin/Morgana signals, and his presence on the failed Mission 2 plus successful Missions 4 and 5 created a mixed read that didn’t fully clear him until late, but his endgame voting lined up well with good’s eventual solve.
player_observations.Iris: As Mordred, she took a bold line by leading Mission 3 and allowing such a heavy fail, which massively scrambled reads and created a lot of noise; the downside was that it eventually pushed the table toward safer, more conservative teams that excluded her from the final missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-good in my voting and mission behavior, especially helping secure the final mission without adding doubt, and I didn’t draw too much suspicion onto myself. I could improve by more vocally pushing structured logic earlier, especially after Mission 2 and Mission 3, to narrow down the evil team faster and better protect Merlin through my reads.

player_observations.Alice: You came off very town-leaning early by leading a clean Mission 1 and were a natural focal point for trust, which made you a plausible Merlin target later. Your mid-game involvement stayed measured, though Mission 2’s fail on a team including you made you an ambiguous but still somewhat trusted figure.
player_observations.Bob: You played the assassin quietly enough that you weren’t loudly flagged as evil, but not so convincingly that the final shot landed on Merlin, suggesting your read of the information and table talk could be sharper. Your participation on the heavily failed Mission 3 helped get that sabotage through but also risked overexposure for the evil team.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced sharing useful suspicions with not over-directing the table, which helped you stay believable but not obvious as Merlin. Your leadership on Mission 4 and then Mission 5 (via influence and trust-building) steered us toward clean teams at crucial moments.
player_observations.Diana: You played a solid, low-drama good game, backing successful teams in the late missions and not overcomplicating the table talk. Your inclusion on Missions 4 and 5 without causing suspicion reinforced you as a reliable, steady presence.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, you leaned into being readable as a potential Merlin, especially around the chaotic Mission 3 fail, but your positioning didn’t fully convince the assassin at the end. Your involvement in both a clean Mission 1 and the disastrous Mission 3 created a mixed record that helped evil for a while but also made you harder to fully clear.
player_observations.Frank: You appeared reliable and cooperative, and your presence on the last two successful missions helped lock in a trustworthy core. Despite being on a failed Mission 2, you managed to keep suspicion relatively low by later aligning with good outcomes and consistent reasoning.
player_observations.Henry: As Percival, you did a decent job not making Merlin too obvious, though your involvement in both a failed (Mission 2) and then successful late missions gave you a swingy profile. Your eventual alignment with the correct endgame teams suggested you were reading the Merlin/Morgana signals reasonably well by the end.
player_observations.Iris: You played Mordred in a way that took advantage of the confusion around Mission 3, helping drive a strong multi-fail that really pressured the good team. However, the aggression of that triple-fail also created a big information spike that, in hindsight, made it easier for good to consolidate into safer teams in Missions 4 and 5.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed reasonably consistent in trusting Charlie and doubting Bob/Eve by the end, and I helped steer Mission 4–5 teams in a good direction after the chaos of Mission 2–3. I could improve by being more vocal and structured about my Percy reads earlier, especially after the single fail on Mission 2, and by challenging the logic behind the Mission 3 team a lot harder.

player_observations.Alice: You projected a very townie, confident presence, and your Mission 4 team was clean and well-constructed, which made you look like a strong info hub (and thus a reasonable assassin target). You did a good job not overreacting to the Mission 2 fail even though you were on it.
player_observations.Bob: You leaned into the chaos on Mission 3 in a way that created a lot of uncertainty and noise, which worked well for you as Assassin. Your social tone was aggressive enough to push suspicion elsewhere without overcommitting to any single narrative.
player_observations.Charlie: You balanced giving direction with not overexposing yourself, especially by backing solid late-game teams without screaming ‘Merlin’. Your reads lined up cleanly with the final good team composition, which made your eventual survival over Alice impressive.
player_observations.Diana: You played a low-drama, stabilizing good role, which helped make the late missions feel safer once you were included. Your willingness to go on back-to-back crucial missions without over-defending yourself made you read quite genuine.
player_observations.Eve: You played a very convincing pseudo-good early on, especially being willing to go on the clean Mission 1 and then the doomed Mission 3, which muddied the waters a lot. Your partnership with Bob in sowing confusion was subtle rather than loud, which is strong for a hidden evil.
player_observations.Frank: You came across as straightforward and pragmatic, especially on the clean Mission 4–5 teams, which helped solidify you as a reliable pick later. Your lack of theatrics made evil pushing on you difficult without looking forced.
player_observations.Grace: Your Mission 1 leadership was quiet but effective, giving good an early success that felt natural rather than staged. Later, you played a more supporting, consensus-building role that helped lock in confidence on the final team rather than trying to re-open old debates.
player_observations.Iris: You did a great job weaponizing the Mission 3 disaster to throw shade broadly, using your Mordred status to stay off Merlin’s radar while still being central to the action. Your earlier willingness to be on mixed teams without looking overly nervous made you a persistent mid-spectrum read instead of an obvious suspect.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well coordinating the heavy sabotage on Mission 3, which created maximum doubt and chaos, and I stayed reasonably unremarkable early so I wasn’t immediately suspected as evil. However, I should have done more to steer late-game team selections away from the all-good lineups in Missions 4 and 5, and I didn’t contribute enough to helping Assassin triangulate Merlin correctly from the information we had.

player_observations.Alice: Played as a very trustworthy anchor early, consistently getting on teams and building a strong good image, which made her a natural but ultimately misleading Merlin candidate.
player_observations.Bob: Took the assassin role quietly, staying just suspicious enough to be plausible evil without drawing overwhelming consensus, but didn’t push strongly persuasive Merlin reads late-game.
player_observations.Charlie: Masterfully low-key Merlin, guiding crucial team selections (especially Mission 4 and 5 compositions) without over-asserting, which kept suspicion off them until the endgame.
player_observations.Diana: Played a steady, low-drama good game, blending into mid-table discussions and accepting good-leaning teams without causing unnecessary waves.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected strong, confident opinions that helped create a Merlin/Morgana ambiguity, especially around Alice, but the coordination didn’t quite translate into the final assassination.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as solidly good and pragmatic, often evaluating teams through result-based logic rather than wild accusations, which made him a stabilizing presence for good.
player_observations.Grace: Early leader who set a clean tone with a successful Mission 1 and then adopted a cautious but cooperative stance, contributing to good’s ability to converge on trusted lineups by the end.
player_observations.Henry: Played Percival with convincingly analytical reasoning, correctly trusting the right signals from Merlin over Morgana, which was key to locking in those final all-good mission teams.
